Title: Sensing the Next Wave (Paid Post by AIG from The New York Times)
Summary:
With billions of sensors woven into the world around us, the Internet of Things is emerging before our eyes.
Close to 60 percent of people are looking to add more “smart” Internet-connected devices to what they already own, according to recent AIG research.
The Internet of Things (IoT) goes way beyond consumer gadgets like smart fitness bands or self-monitoring refrigerators.
IoT aims to make our lives safer and easier, which is part of the reason companies and individuals are so willing to use connected devices.
In research conducted by AIG, more than half of the respondents were willing to share data to make their family safer or to improve their life.
Text:
With billions of sensors woven into the world around us, the Internet of Things is emerging before our eyes. Close to 60 percent of people are looking to add more “smart” Internet-connected devices to what they already own, according to recent AIG research.

The Internet of Things (IoT) goes way beyond consumer gadgets like smart fitness bands or self-monitoring refrigerators. This is the start of a new, more efficient industrial ecosystem.

AIG’s research finds that individuals are excited for these changes, as more than twice as many people are optimistic than fearful about IoT, which is the connectivity of the Internet with everyday objects around us.

By 2020, it is estimated there will be 40 or 50 billion “connected things” worldwide, according to Rand Europe. The invention of the printing press in 1450 meant more than just the fact that books could be made more quickly and efficiently, “it impacted everything — culture, communication, communities, education. IoT has that same potential reach,” says Shawn DuBravac, chief economist for the Consumer Technology Association.

IoT aims to make our lives safer and easier, which is part of the reason companies and individuals are so willing to use connected devices. In research conducted by AIG, more than half of the respondents were willing to share data to make their family safer or to improve their life.

Title: Cars 2025 (Paid Post by Goldman Sachs from The New York Times)
Summary:
Concerns about greenhouse gases and pollution are driving an industry-wide change in the way cars are powered.
By 2025, 25% of cars sold will have electric engines, up from 5% today.
That means automakers will need to make internal combustion engines more efficient to comply with new standards.
The Japanese government has set a target price of ¥2.2million—around US $18,000—for fuel-cell vehicles by 2025.
While they would still be a small niche in global sales, that target price would allow them to become competitive with popular hybrids.
Text:
The car of 2025 won’t look like today’s automobiles. Here are the trends reshaping the way we drive.

Concerns about greenhouse gases and pollution are driving an industry-wide change in the way cars are powered. Regulations on fuel economy and CO2 emissions are forcing carmakers to make engines more efficient. By 2025, 25% of cars sold will have electric engines, up from 5% today. But most of those will be hybrids, and 95% of cars will still rely on fossil fuels for at least part of their power. That means automakers will need to make internal combustion engines more efficient to comply with new standards.

The development of alternative power sources such as fuel cells will add to overall efficiency, but only if people can afford them. The Japanese government has set a target price of ¥2.2million—around US $18,000—for fuel-cell vehicles by 2025. While they would still be a small niche in global sales, that target price would allow them to become competitive with popular hybrids.

Title: Driving forces (Paid Post by Canon from The New York Times)
Summary:
"For me, it grew out of a love for things that visually excited me in nature," Floto says.
Warner grew up in upstate New York and, like Floto, took a “long road” to photography.
While Nancy may have guided him there, Matt quickly found his own style of photography before joining his sister in a wedding photography business.
For Nancy, wedding photography is a stark departure from her previous project, which was documenting the life-ending cancer diagnoses of their mother, and soon after, their father.
The brother-sister combination is one that has proven to be an asset in the world of wedding photography.
Text:
Driving Forces

The people — and things — that push photographers to capture the best images. INSPIRATION TAKES MANY FORMS for a photographer. It can come from what they are shooting to what’s around them — or even the lighting at a certain time of day. That spark can also come from a spouse or sibling, who, in working closely with one another, can push their vision further than what they thought possible in order to create that perfect image. The following photographers tell us how they began their journeys, and what, or who, drives their work to ever more impressive levels of artistry.

Floto+Warner When Jeremy Floto met Cassandra Warner at the Rochester Institute of Technology's photography school, there was immediate chemistry in front of and behind the lens. "It was fast," Warner remembers. "We were shooting on the same camera and we couldn’t tell whose photos were whose." That similarity of style, coupled with a professional competitiveness to "get the shot," has resulted in an artistic collaboration whose design-infused photography often contains surprising visual metaphors. Floto grew up outside of Nevada and meandered through jobs as a ski patrolman and paramedic before finding his calling in photography and design. "For me, it grew out of a love for things that visually excited me in nature," Floto says. Warner grew up in upstate New York and, like Floto, took a “long road” to photography. Together, they discovered a new perspective on subjects that excited both. They honed their style by taking pictures of the “suburban abandoned strip malls” and the “bleak, desolate landscape” surrounding RIT, Warner says.

"It was new for me because I grew up out West; and for Cassandra it was something that was deeply personal," Floto says. "I think that combined vision is one of the great things about working together — even though we've crafted an aesthetic vision together, the reasons behind our interest in certain subjects is different. There's a synergy to the way we work and we both bring our own perspective." The married pair’s differing perspectives combine to create a cohesive vision that art lovers and clients are innately drawn to. "We get to go places that people don’t have a chance to go. There is something that’s great about being able to translate that visual drama into something for people to look at," Floto says. While working together can create a cohesive vision, it can also spur creativity when there is a mental block. "Sometimes you don’t see 'it' but one person does, and you can feed off of that energy and push each other," Warner says. Working as a team allows Floto+Warner to pursue what they love, together. "We love to travel, and we get to enjoy each other's company when we go to shoot," she says.

Matt Borowick and Nancy Borowick It wasn't hard for Matt Borowick to find a path to photography — his sister, Nancy, had already paved the way for him as an award-winning photographer herself. "Photography was something our older sister did in high school, and so I did it, and Matty followed," says Nancy Borowick, three years Matt’s senior. While Nancy may have guided him there, Matt quickly found his own style of photography before joining his sister in a wedding photography business. During an event, Nancy will take the lead and take primary photography of family and guests. Meanwhile, Matt canvases the space for striking landscape shots and hidden details, exploring the world using a detailed combination of macro- and micro-environments that reveal a unique style. Matt will often walk away from the ceremony or reception and find a location that can truly define the ethereal feel of the evening. Using long-exposure shots, Matt’s photography can capture the seemingly infinite stars in the night sky or a vast, mountainous landscape surrounding a valley. Or, just as easily, he has the ability to show you the minute detail and delicate beauty of engraved jewelry or blossoming flowers. For Nancy, wedding photography is a stark departure from her previous project, which was documenting the life-ending cancer diagnoses of their mother, and soon after, their father. Her wedding during this time was the one bright spot from the cloud that weighed over the family for those two years. "It allowed us to think about something else," says Nancy. Following the passing of their parents, the siblings turned to weddings to rediscover their passion for photography.















"I needed something that I could find great joy in photographing," Nancy says. The first wedding they shot was just for fun, but Nancy realized how happy it made her, and a business was born. For Matt, the feeling that he gets at weddings is one that doesn't compare with any other kind of photography. "Whenever I leave weddings, I feel refreshed, happy, joyous — and so exhausted," he says. The brother-sister combination is one that has proven to be an asset in the world of wedding photography. It allows for each partner to honestly critique the other’s work and push them further as an artist. Plus, it’s never lonely. "It’s nice because often in this business you are a lone wolf — it's nice to have a pack," says Matt. "People see that we're family, and view us as an extended part of their family," Nancy says.

Ralph Smith Sometimes it's working with a partner that brings out an artist’s creative side. Other times it's the solitude of nature that allows one to see things in a way others don’t. The wide-open vistas of the Scottish Highlands is one muse for Ralph Smith, who uses his photographs of high, open valleys as a starting point to craft his hyper-colored images that conjure thoughts of barren interplanetary landscapes. "I'm inspired by the sublime," he says. "If you can find that scene that is horrific and humbling simultaneously — it is a personal experience — but I think it can be conveyed in a photograph," Smith says. Smith's drive was sparked by his high school photography teacher. After graduation, that passion led to an internship with famed photographer Arnold Newman and, later, a degree from the Rochester Institute of Technology for photography. While starting his professional career in studio still life, Smith thought back to his life growing up in the outdoors of Minnesota. His studio work allowed him to create sharp images for magazines, but he craved new challenges. A trip to California’s Big Sur marked the beginning of his experimental, color-enhanced landscapes.
